round_best: Develop a hybrid diffusion model that incorporates Lévy processes as the underlying stochastic drivers instead of the traditional Brownian motion. The Lévy processes are characterized by their heavy tails and better suit the nature of data distributions involving rare or extreme events. This model can be optimized by adaptively tuning the parameters of the Lévy process (like skewness and scale) based on the observed data, using a meta-learning approach that adjusts these parameters across different training epochs to improve the fidelity of event representation.

round_best: Introduce a hierarchical Bayesian framework in the diffusion model where the prior distribution is governed by a mixture of Gaussian and Lévy processes, allowing the model to switch between these processes depending on the characteristics of the data segment being generated. round_best: Explore the use of tempered stable distributions instead of standard Lévy processes in the diffusion model to provide a more controlled approach to handling heavy tails.
